An efficient method for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from CO2 and epoxides using an effective two-component catalyst system: Polymer-supported quaternary onium salts and aqueous solutions of metal salts Agnieszka Siewniak ⁎ Katarzyna Jasiak Stefan Baj Silesian University of Technology, Department of Chemical Organic Technology and Petrochemistry, Krzywoustego 4, 44-100 Gliwice, Poland Silesian University of Technology, Department of Chemical Organic Technology and Petrochemistry Krzywoustego 4 Gliwice 44-100 Poland ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +48 32 2372917; fax: +48 32 2371032. Graphical abstract A highly efficient method for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from carbon dioxide and epoxides in the presence of polymer-supported quaternary onium salts (PS-Q+X−) and aqueous solution of metal salts under mild conditions, is described. In comparison with conventional homogeneous catalysts, immobilized tributylmethylammonium chloride (PS-TBMAC) is a recyclable, effective catalyst for the studied reaction. The presence of an aqueous solution of zinc iodide as a co-catalyst enhances significantly the catalytic activity of PS-TBMAC. Using this two-component catalyst system (polymer-supported quaternary onium salts and aqueous solution of metal salts), the reaction of CO2 with selected epoxides can be conducted with high product yield (71–91%) and selectivity (97–99%) under mild reaction conditions (temperature 110°C and initial CO2 pressure 0.9MPa). Propylene carbonate was obtained in the best yield (91%). In addition, the advantages of this method include a short reaction time, solvent-free conditions, and an easy separation of catalyst system. Keywords Cyclic alkylene carbonates Carbon dioxide Epoxides Polymer-supported quaternary onium salts Metal salts 1 Introduction More stringent regulations for allowable emissions of greenhouse gases, including carbon dioxide, have caused increasing interest in methods for their reduction. Carbon dioxide can be used as a cheap, readily available, non-flammable and non-toxic resource of carbon in chemical syntheses [1]. The processing of carbon dioxide into useful chemical products is one of the forward directions in CO2 management. Amongst these products, five-membered alkylene carbonates (1,3-dioxolan-2-ones) are taken into consideration. It is obvious that the use of CO2 in chemical syntheses will not prevent the greenhouse effect, as it is impossible to considerably reduce the amounts of this gas in the Earth's atmosphere. However, the idea of using it in the production of chemicals agrees most of all with the principles of “green chemistry”, which concern the reuse of waste materials and the use of safe reagents, although not only, to prevent environmental pollution. Cyclic alkylene carbonates, especially ethylene carbonate and propylene carbonate, are characterized by a broad spectrum of applications [2]. Amongst others, they are used as plasticizers [3], electrolytes for lithium-ion batteries [4], paint strippers [5], reaction intermediates in fine chemicals synthesis, and in the pharmaceutical and cosmetic industries [6,7]. Moreover, they play an important role in the synthesis of polymers [8], e.g. polycarbonates [9], and they are used as polar aprotic solvents [10–13]. The synthesis of cyclic alkylene carbonates as a result of the reaction of carbon dioxide with epoxide is one of the CO2 reactions of industrial importance. The process is a strongly exothermic one; however it requires catalytic activation because of the thermodynamic stability of carbon dioxide. The use of relatively inexpensive reagents is an advantage of the method, and reaction runs with 100% atom economy. The parameters of the process depend mainly on the catalytic system used. Amongst others, the following substances are used as catalysts for reaction to produce alkylene carbonates from CO2: alkali metal salts [14,15], metal oxides [16], metal complexes [17–22]. Recently, several review papers have been published, which indicates a continued interest in the development of methods for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from carbon dioxide and epoxide [1,23–29]. In recent years, increased interest in use of ionic liquids (IL) both as solvents as well as catalysts, has been observed. This is a result of their many unique properties, such as thermal and chemical stabilities, high activity, and negligible vapour pressure. Peng and Deng, as some of the first, described the application of 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate as a catalyst in reaction between propylene oxide and CO2. Selectivity of the reaction was 100%. The ionic liquid could be reused even five times over without a significant decrease in catalytic activity [30]. In order to further improve the yield of the synthesis of cyclic carbonates, some catalyst systems consisting of ionic liquid and Lewis acidic compounds as co-catalysts were investigated [31,32]. Kawanami et al. reported the reaction between epoxide and CO2 under supercritical conditions in the presence of ionic liquid containing 1-alkyl-3-methylimidazolium cation in structure. An increase of length of the alkyl chain in cation of ionic liquid caused an increase of yield and selectivity of the reaction, and a significant shortening of the reaction time. It may be a result of the better solubility of epoxide and CO2 in such ionic liquids with a longer alkyl chain [33]. There are also reports regarding the use of immobilized ionic liquids as catalysts for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates. For example, Shen et al. reported that the synthesis of propylene carbonate with a good conversion of propylene oxide, catalyzed by ionic liquid, functionalized silica gel [34]. Special attention should be paid to quaternary onium salts because of their high catalytic activity. In a patent issued in 1956, quaternary onium salts were described as highly effective catalysts for the synthesis of alkylene carbonates by the reaction of carbon dioxide with an appropriate epoxide. Cyclic carbonates were obtained with a yield of 50–97% depending on the type of epoxide and reaction conditions [35]. Since then, significant progress has been made to improve the efficiency of these catalysts. The results reported by Caló et al. show that the use of a TBAI/TBAB mixture, instead of the tetrabutylammonium bromide alone, caused a shortening of the reaction time [36]. Moreover, Ra et al. found that the catalytic activity of the quaternary ammonium salts depended on the melting points of the halides. The yield of reaction in the presence of tetramethylammonium bromide or tetraethylammonium bromide was low. This may be due to the fact that these ammonium bromides have high mp's, i.e. they are solids at the reaction temperature [37]. The catalyst systems, including both quaternary onium salts, and salts or complexes of metals, were started to be used to increase the yield of the synthesis of alkylene carbonates. In case of the synthesis of cyclic carbonates in the presence of tetrabutylammonium iodide and zinc iodide, the efficiency of such a catalytic system depended on TBAI/ZnI2 molar ratio, which should have a 4:1 optimum. The yield of reaction varied between 90 and 98%, depending on the type of epoxide. This method was mainly used for the synthesis of alkylene carbonates containing an alkyl or aryl group [38]. In 2012, cyanocobalamin and tetrabutylammonium halide were used by Bai et al. as an excellent catalyst system for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates [39]. The yield of this reaction mostly depended on the type of quaternary onium salt anion, and increased in the order of TBAC<TBAF< TBAI<TBAB. After the reaction, cyanocobalamin was reused three times; however a significant decrease in the yield of propylene carbonate was observed with every use of cyanocobalamin. SalenCo(III) (Cl3CCO2)/PTAT have also been reported as a catalytic system for the reaction between epoxide and CO2. The use of such a catalytic system has allowed for the obtaining of cyclic carbonates with a high yield under extremely mild conditions (atmospheric pressure, room temperature) [40]. There are several reported works on the reaction between epoxide and CO2 in the presence of two-component catalyst systems [41,42]. It should be noted that the difficult separation of the catalyst from the post-reaction mixture is one of the main problems that occur when homogeneous catalysts are used. One of the solutions is to immobilize quaternary onium salts and ionic liquids on catalyst insoluble supports, which will allow to connect effectively advantages of homogeneous catalysis with a heterogeneous one. In recent years, various solid materials such as inorganic materials [43,44], carbon nanotubes [45], polymer supports [46,47] and magnetic nanoparticles [48] have been used for the immobilization of homogeneous catalysts. In the case of using immobilized tetraalkyl-onium salts, the reactions between CO2 and epoxide were usually carried out at high temperatures, 150–160°C [46,49–51], and/or under high pressure between 4 and 10MPa [44,49–52], and the reaction times were usually 6–24h. Therefore, our challenge was to develop a method with an active catalytic system containing polymer-supported quaternary salts which simultaneously allows for easy separation of the catalyst and its recycling and to conduct the reaction under relatively mild conditions. Herein, for the reaction of carbon dioxide with epoxides, catalyst systems consisting of quaternary onium salts immobilized on polymeric supports and metal salts, e.g. ZnI2, were used. We found that using an aqueous solution of ZnI2 can improve the reaction yield. Using propylene oxide (PO) as a model substrate, comparative experiments of the reaction of CO2 with PO were carried out in order to determine the effects of catalytic reaction parameters, including temperature, initial CO2 pressure and the effect of the amount of co-catalyst on the propylene carbonate's (PC) yield and selectivity (Eq. 1). (Eq. 1 The model reaction between CO2 and PO.) 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of polymer-supported quaternary ammonium salts The method of quaternization of trialkylamine with chloromethylated polystyrene has been described elsewhere [53]. Four cross-linked polystyrene matrixes (PS-1–4) differing in size of particles, cross-linking degree, and number of functional groups, were used in the synthesis of immobilized catalysts based quaternary onium salts. Typical procedure: 2–3g of polymer support (chloromethylated polystyrene cross-linked with divinylbenzene) and 3-mol excess of amine (tributylamine TBA, triethylamine TEA or trihexylamine THA) in 4ml of anhydrous N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) was refluxed for 6 days at 60°C using 500rpm speed of agitation. Upon completion of the reaction, the catalyst was filtered out and washed successively by methanol, acetone and methanol again. Next, the catalyst was purified by Soxhlet extraction performed for 60h using diethyl ether as solvent. Afterwards, the catalyst was dried under vacuum (10mbar, 10h). Catalyst characterization: Elementary analysis was performed using a PerkinElmer 2400 series 2 CHNO/S analyzer. Cysteine and acetanilide were used as standards. The results of elementary analysis are shown in Table 1 . 2.2 Synthesis of cyclic carbonates All the reactions were carried out in a 100ml stainless steel pressure reactor (Mettler Toledo) with a mechanical stirrer (pitched-blade) immersed in solid-state thermostat (EasyMax™ 102) with an automatic temperature control system. The pressure reactor was also equipped with temperature and pressure sensors and rapture disc. Typical procedure: PO (15ml, 0.21mol), the appropriate amount of a two-component catalyst system consisting of quaternary onium salts and metal salts, were added into a reactor. The reactor was purged with carbon dioxide twice, and then heated to the desired temperature (50–130°C). CO2 was charged into a reactor from a reservoir tank to a chosen constant pressure (0.4–1.2MPa). iControl® software was used to monitor the reaction progress. Analysis: After the reaction was completed, the reactor was cooled to ambient temperature, and the excess CO2 was vented. The catalyst system was separated from the reaction mixture by simple filtration. Samples from organic layer were taken, dissolved in CH2Cl2, and analyzed by gas chromatography (PerkinElmer GC, Clarus 500) equipped with a capillary column (SPB™-5: 30m×0.25mm×0.25μm film thickness). 1-Octane was used as an internal standard substance. In order to determine any by-products in the reaction between CO2 and epoxides, GC–MS analysis was performed on GC–MS system (Agilent Technologies 7890A GC system, Agilent Technologies 5975C inert XL EI/CI MSD with Triple-Axis Detector) equipped with a capillary column (HP5/MS-5: 30m×250μm×0.25μm film thickness). Product isolation: After the completion of the reaction, the mixture was cooled to room temperature and filtered to remove solid ZnI2 and PS-TBMAC. The solid was washed with CH2Cl2 (3× 10ml) and then three times with 5ml of water. The organic phase was dried over anhydrous MgSO4 and distilled under reduced pressure. As for the synthesis of styrene carbonate, its purification was obtained by column chromatography using 20% hexane in chloroform as the eluting solvent. Next, the reaction product was analyzed by 1H NMR spectroscopy (Varian 600MHz NMR System) and GC–MS. The yields of obtained cyclic carbonates were determined on the basis of isolated products according to the equation: Y = Δ n epoxide n o epoxide = ν epoxide ν CC ⋅ n CC n o epoxide ⋅ 100 % where n, number of moles; n o, initial number of moles; CC, cyclic carbonate; ν, stoichiometric coefficients, ν =1 in this case.or on the basis of the variation of the product amount with time determined by GC analysis of the samples taken from the organic phase. During the synthesis of cyclic carbonates only observed by-products were the corresponding glycols. Due to the fact that we could not measure changes in the concentrations of propylene oxide by GC analysis, the selectivity of the reaction between CO2 and epoxide to the cyclic carbonate was determined according to the equation: S = n CC n CC + n G ⋅ 100 % where n, number of moles; CC, cyclic carbonate; G, glycol. Catalyst recycling: After the completion of the reaction, the immobilized catalyst was simply recovered by filtration, washed with dichloromethane (3× 10ml). During the filtration of the reaction mixture, a part of zinc iodide crystallized on the filter. This precipitate can be easily separated. The remaining part of zinc iodide was separated by addition of water (15ml) to the filtrate – organic phase. Addition of water caused precipitation of zinc iodide, which then could be easily recovered by filtration and after a preparation of 77% aqueous solution, can be used again. The separated PS-TBMAC during the filtration was dried in vacuum and then reused for the next run. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Choice of the catalytic system The study on the model reaction between CO2 and propylene oxide was started by examining the catalytic reactivity of the polymer-supported quaternary ammonium salts. Tributylmethylammonium chloride immobilized on polystyrene cross-linked with divinylbenzene (PS-TBMAC) was chosen as a catalyst. The reactions were carried out under the following conditions: temperature 110°C and initial CO2 pressure 0.9MPa, agitation speed 500rpm. As shown in Table 2 , the yield of propylene carbonate (PC) in the presence PS-TBMAC was only 48% after 4h (entry 1). To increase the efficiency of the reaction, the model reaction was carried out with dry zinc iodide as a co-catalyst. ZnI2 can act as a Lewis acid, which is involved in the activation of the epoxide [54]. The use of this two-component catalyst system resulted in an increase in the PC yield to 76%, and the shortening of the reaction time to 3h (Table 2, entry 2). It is also known that the water added to the reaction system on the one hand can activate the epoxide ring opening, whilst on the other hand it can contribute to a hydrolysis reaction of epoxide. Water was therefore added in the form of an aqueous solution of ZnI2, instead of directly to the reaction mixture. The combination of PS-TBMAC with the aqueous ZnI2 solution caused an increase in the PC yield to 91% after 2h (Table 2, entry 3). This promising result prompted us to investigate the effect of the addition of water as well as the manner for its introduction into the reaction mixture, which is described below (see Section 3.6). Control reactions showed that in the absence of a catalyst or only in the presence of the polymer support or ZnI2, no reaction took place (Table 2, entries 4–6). The PC yield in the reaction of CO2 with PO using PS-TBMAC and H2O was 55% (Table 2, entry 7). To compare the catalytic activity of PS-TBMAC with its homogeneous counterparts, reactions in the presence of catalysts such as TBMAC and BTBAC, with and without ZnI2 as a co-catalyst, were carried out (Table 2, entries 8–13). The results indicate that an immobilized catalyst on the polymer support PS-TBMAC showed higher activity in model reaction in comparison to homogeneous quaternary salts. GC analysis revealed that trialkylamine, which is the product of the catalyst's degradation, was present in the post-reaction mixture. The results indicate that polymer-supported quaternary onium salt was more stable at a high reaction temperature than a non-immobilized catalyst [55]. In the case of the reaction carried out in the presence of TBAC as a catalyst (Table 2, entries 12 and 13, respectively), the formation of propylene carbonate and 1,2-propylene glycol (confirmed by GC–MS analysis) was observed, which resulted in a low selectivity of the reaction to the propylene carbonate (77–79%). This low selectivity is probably due to the fact that the tetrabutylammonium chloride hydrate was used in these experiments and a Karl Fischer titration showed a high content of water in the catalyst. In the literature, there are reports concerning the use of supported quaternary onium salts as catalysts for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from CO2 and epoxides. For example, He et al. reported the reaction between epoxide and carbon dioxide under supercritical conditions (temperature 120°C, initial CO2 pressure 8MPa, reaction time 6h) in the presence of poly(ethylene glycol)-supported quaternary ammonium salt [56]. More recently, polymer-supported quaternary phosphonium salt was described as a highly effective catalyst for the synthesis of alkylene carbonates. The reaction was carried out under the following conditions: 150°C and 5MPa, 6h [51]. In comparison with these above methods, we have proposed the use of catalytic system PS-TBMAC/aq. ZnI2 which allowed for the obtaining of cyclic carbonates with a comparatively high yield under milder reaction conditions (temperature 110°C, initial CO2 pressure 0.9MPa, reaction time 2h). Going on the results obtained, it can be stated that the PS-TBMAC/aq. ZnI2 system appeared the most effective catalyst for the model reaction between CO2 and propylene oxide. 3.2 The effect of reaction conditions The effect of reaction parameters including temperature and initial CO2 pressure on the yield of propylene carbonate synthesis in the presence of system PS-TBMAC/aq. ZnI2, was determined. Fig. 1 shows the dependence of the PC yield on the reaction temperature. With a temperature rise from 50 to 110°C, the PC yield and reaction rate increased, but a further increase in temperature did not accelerate the reaction nor increase its yield. This may be due to the fact that solubility of CO2 in the reaction system decreases in temperatures above 110°C. Consequently, due to a lower CO2 content in the reaction mixture, we did not observe the acceleration of the model reaction and an increase in the PC yield at 130°C. A similar phenomenon was described by Park [45]. It should be noted that throughout the whole examined temperature range, selectivity remained constant. The reaction yield is also dependent on the initial pressure of CO2. Fig. 2 shows that increasing the pressure from 0.4MPa to 0.9MPa significantly affected the yield of propylene carbonate causing its increase from 2 to 91%. High pressure can effectively improve the absorption of CO2 into the solution of epoxide, contributing to a shift in the equilibrium towards the formation of the PC. However, if the CO2 pressure increased above 0.9MPa, the PC yield drop was observed. This may be due to the fact that the higher concentration of CO2 in the reaction mixture could hinder the interaction between epoxide and the catalyst [45,46]. 3.3 The effect of the type of co-catalyst In order to determine the effect of the type of co-catalyst for the reaction of CO2 with propylene oxide, a series of metal salts, ZnI2, ZnBr2, ZnCl2, CaCl2, were used. These experiments were carried out in the presence of a constant amount of catalyst (PS-TBMAC – 2.14mmol) under the optimized conditions (temperature 110°C, initial CO2 pressure 0.9MPa). Metal salts were added to the reaction mixture as dry solids. Table 3 shows that both the type of anion and the cation of the co-catalyst were important for the activity of a two-component catalyst system. The PC yield was increased with an increase of the nucleophilicity of anion in the co-catalyst: ZnCl2 <ZnBr2 <ZnI2 [54]. To improve the coordination of the epoxide by metal salts, the model reaction should be carried in the presence of stronger Lewis acid. Therefore, based on the results, the catalytic activity of the co-catalyst increased in the order of CaCl2 <ZnCl2. 3.4 The effect of type of polymer-supported quaternary salt The structure of the polymer-supported quaternary onium salts: cross-linking degree, size of particles, number of functional groups, also has an effect on the course of the model reaction. The experiments were carried out under identical conditions: 110°C and 0.9MPa, 500rpm. The PC yield affected by the type of amine which was quaternizated with chloromethylated polystyrene cross-linked with 1% DVB: tributylamine (91%)>triethylamine (70%)>trihexylamine (43%) (Table 4 , entries 1, 6 and 7). The catalyst with tributylmethylammonium group was more active than one with tributylmethylphosphonium group (the PC yield 48%) immobilized on the same polymer support (Table 4, entries 1 and 2). Moreover, catalysts based on tributylamine immobilized on polymer supports of various parameters, were also tested. As shown in Table 4, the PC yield decreased from 91% to 62% with an increasing degree of cross-linking from 1% to 2% (entries 1 and 3). This may be due to the difficult access of the reactants to the active sites of the immobilized catalyst. Among catalysts synthesized from tributylamine low PC yield was obtained when it was immobilized on a polymer-support of the highest degree of cross-linking: 5.5% and the largest size of particles: 16–50 mesh (Table 4, entry 4). Similarly, the use of commercially available ion-exchange resins such as Amberlite 410 and Amberlite 400, with short alkyl groups at the nitrogen atom of the functional group, with a high degree of cross-linking and large-diameter particles, allowed propylene carbonate with a yield of only 21% and 17% to be obtained (Table 4, entries 8 and 9). 3.5 The effect of amount of catalyst PS-TBMAC The influence of the amount of quaternary salt on the course of the synthesis of propylene carbonate was examined using PS-TBMAC in quantities of 1.7, 2.14, and 3.21mmol (0.5, 1.0, 1.5mol % relative to PO). Other reaction conditions remained unchanged: 110°C, 0.9MPa, 500rpm, aqueous solution of ZnI2. As shown in Table 5 , the reaction yield increased with the rise of the quantity of catalyst to 2.14mmol. By comparison, an increase in the amount of PS-TBMAC above 2.14mmol has an insignificant effect on the reaction yield. In consequence, we chose 2.14mmol as the optimal amount of PS-TBMAC catalyst for the reaction of CO2 with propylene oxide. 3.6 The effect of water As shown in Table 2, the two-component catalyst system PS-TBMAC/dry solid ZnI2 exhibited an unsatisfactory yield of a model reaction between propylene oxide and CO2 (76%). Therefore, in order to improve the obtained result, the effect of the addition of water was tested. The investigated molar ratio of H2O/PO ranged from 0 to 0.3. Other reaction conditions were unchanged (temperature 110°C and initial CO2 pressure 0.9MPa). The results summarized in Table 6 indicate that in the case of our two-component catalytic system: PS-TBMAC/dry solid ZnI2, the addition of water directly into the reaction mixture led to a decrease of the PC yield (33–64%). Simultaneously, it can be seen that for a molar ratio of H2O/PO higher than 0.05 the selectivity of the process decreased (Table 6, entries 1 and 2). This can be explained by the formation of 1,2-propylene glycol from PO in the presence of water. 1,2-propylene glycol was determined by GC–MS analysis. Small amounts of water (the molar ratio of H2O/PO below 0.05) did not cause a significant drop of the reaction selectivity. In the next step, we wanted to check whether the manner for introduction of water into the reaction mixture may affect the reaction course. Therefore, for the H2O/PO molar ratio of 0.015, we conducted the model reaction in the presence of water, which was added to the reaction mixture as an aqueous solution of zinc iodide (H2O/ZnI2 molar ratio of 5). It can be seen that the PC yield increased (91%) when an aqueous solution of zinc iodide was used (Table 7 , entry 1) instead of ZnI2 and water added separately (64%). As pointed out by Yamaguchi [57], zinc iodide (II) can form complexes with water in aqueous solutions, when the molar ratio of H2O/ZnI2 ranges from 5 to 10. For this reason, additionally, we investigated the synthesis of propylene carbonate in the presence of aqueous solutions of zinc iodide in which molar ratio of H2O/ZnI2 was 8 and greater than 10 (Table 7, entries 2 and 3). For the molar H2O/ZnI2 ratio of 8 the PC yield was high (82%), as in the case of using aqueous solution of zinc iodide at H2O/ZnI2 molar ratio of 5. The zinc iodide probably formed a complex with the water, which caused an increase in activity. Use of an aqueous solution of ZnBr2 (H2O/ZnBr2 molar ratio of 5) also resulted in a good yield of propylene carbonate (Table 7, entry 4). We also investigated the effect of the use of aqueous solution of calcium chloride (H2O/CaCl2 molar ratio of 5) on the course of a model reaction, but a similar dependence was not observed in this case. Based on Refs. [54,58], we can assume that complex of ZnI2 with water (L x ZnI2 in Scheme 1 ) might play a key role in promoting the activation of the epoxy ring. An anion of quaternary onium salt makes a nucleophilic attack on a less-hindered carbon atom in the epoxide ring, producing a metal alkoxide anion, which interacts with the CO2 molecule to form a zinc carbonate active species. Next, five-membered cyclic carbonate is produced as a result of intramolecular cyclic elimination. Herein, the halide complexes of zinc (II) in aqueous solution could be effective as co-catalysts for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates. 3.7 Synthesis of cyclic carbonates from various epoxides and CO2 The two-component catalyst system PS-TBMAC/aq. ZnI2 was applied to the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from the selected epoxides, namely: propylene oxide, epichlorohydrin, styrene oxide, and cyclohexene oxide (Table 8 ). The experiments were carried out under optimized conditions: temperature 110°C, initial CO2 pressure 0.9MPa, 500rpm. It is worth mentioning that the highest product yield (91%) was observed for propylene oxide. Nevertheless, carbonates obtained from epichlorohydrin or styrene oxide were also successfully synthesized with yields of 85% and 71%, respectively. Cyclohexene oxide was the least active amongst all the epoxides used, which can be the result of higher steric hindrance at the C atom of the cyclohexene ring [45]. 3.8 Catalyst recycling test To examine the reusability of PS-TBMAC, the model reaction between CO2 and propylene oxide was carried out under optimized reaction conditions (110°C, CO2 pressure 0.9MPa, 2h). For each cycle we added a fresh 77% aqueous solution of zinc iodide as a co-catalyst. The immobilized catalyst PS-TBMAC was easily separated from the post-reaction mixture by filtration, washed with CH2Cl2 and water, and after drying in vacuum, was used directly for the next run. ZnI2 can be also recovered and recycled in the form of an aqueous solution. The yield of the model reaction was slightly lower (88%) than with a fresh solution of zinc iodide (91%). This probability may be due to losses in the recovery of zinc iodide. As shown in Fig. 3 , the catalyst (PS-TBMAC) could be reused three times without a significant decrease in the catalytic activity. However, after four cycles a slight catalytic activity drop was observed, which is likely due to the decomposition of the catalyst functional groups, confirmed by the presence of trace amounts of tributylamine in the reaction mixture (determined by GC–MS analysis). Moreover, in each cycle the reaction was proceeded with an almost constant PC selectivity (94–97%). Therefore, it can be concluded that the possibility of easy separation of this catalyst from a post-reaction mixture and its recyclability are advantages of the proposed catalytic system. These benefits are important for reduction of the process cost. 4 Conclusion Identifying the optimized reaction conditions, including the type of catalyst, temperature, CO2 pressure, amount of catalyst, and addition of water has led to the obtaining of cyclic carbonates with a high yield (71–91%). The immobilization of quaternary onium played an important role in the catalytic performance. PS-TBMAC is characterized by low cost, reusability, and good catalytic activity. An addition of 77% aqueous solution of zinc iodide resulted in an increased reaction rate and yield of PC, as compared to the reaction without a co-catalyst. The advantages of cyclic carbonate synthesis using an effective two-component catalyst system consisting of PS-TBMAC and aqueous solution of ZnI2, are: mild conditions, short reaction time, and high product yield and selectivity. Therefore, in the future, the proposed method could be applied on an industrial scale. coredata.dc:description: A highly efficient method for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from carbon dioxide and epoxides in the presence of polymer-supported quaternary onium salts (PS-Q+X−) and aqueous solution of metal salts under mild conditions, is described. In comparison with conventional homogeneous catalysts, immobilized tributylmethylammonium chloride (PS-TBMAC) is a recyclable, effective catalyst for the studied reaction. The presence of an aqueous solution of zinc iodide as a co-catalyst enhances significantly the catalytic activity of PS-TBMAC. Using this two-component catalyst system (polymer-supported quaternary onium salts and aqueous solution of metal salts), the reaction of CO2 with selected epoxides can be conducted with high product yield (71–91%) and selectivity (97–99%) under mild reaction conditions (temperature 110°C and initial CO2 pressure 0.9MPa). Propylene carbonate was obtained in the best yield (91%). In addition, the advantages of this method include a short reaction time, solvent-free conditions, and an easy separation of catalyst system.
coredata.dc:title: An efficient method for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from CO2 and epoxides using an effective two-component catalyst system: Polymer-supported quaternary onium salts and aqueous solutions of metal salts
